bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 11, 1900

div1.p: Reed discusses finances and his plans for Keewaydin. He describes a visit inland and jokes about his weight.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 11, 1900
div1.p:
Here it is
Friday evening & I haven't written
a word to the sweet little wo-
man who wrote me such a
nice letter, last saturday. That
letter was a little more like
your darling self -- although you
keep harping on “those bills”,-
Do pray let up on that subject,
sweetheart- So you really heard
that “yarn” from poor, good
old Beehner? I thought that it
would reach you and lead
to your being disappointed- It
was really too bad, my precious
heart, but your “Mosquito”- was
not to blame, this time- I am
glad the check arrived prompt-
ly and had hoped that it would
cheer you up a weet bit-
Just keep away from Wood-
ward and Lothrop for a while
and your bank account will
begin to increase, especially
as you don't have to send any-
thing to Johnnie Moore. Between
those two, we manage, lovie, dear,
to spend most of our spare
change- But we did so well
last year, dearest oomsey, that we
ought to feel encouraged very
much. I think that we can
add $1200.00 to that other $700.00, this
year- You just see if we don't!
I know that you were rejoiced
to see that rosy-cheeked daughter
come “moseying” back from
Annapolis- (I don't know why I
will persist in spelling that word
with one n.) I didn't write on
yesterday, because Cap't. Slocum
invited me to go 15 miles into
the Country with him and I couldn't
well refuse- we drove through
a very pretty part of the Island,
and I did wish so much for my darl-
ing wifie, that she might see
some of the pretty views- But
I can't let my precious Miss Gouty
travel on the ocean at this
season of the year. No, no, my
sweetheart, you could never
stand it- You can get along
and be happy without seeing
this part of the Island just
now. I wish that I owned
5 acres near the ocean here,
for we could make it a veri-
table paradise, but our sweet
Keewaydin is pretty enough
for us & we can find need
for all of our spare cash
there- I am simply frantic for
spring to come so that we can
run up there & see those darling
trees sprout out in the woodland,
and to make that garden grow
once more- Their my precious
wifie will get all of those gou-
ty humors out of her and be able
to run around and be merry
once more- You had better keep
your “weather eye” open for a
good cook and bottle-washer!
Somebody told me, this afternoon,
that Mrs. Barden had come down
to Havana, but that she didn't
like it very much- Am glad that
you saw Lt. Cooke- I wish that
I could get down to see Dar-
boy before I leave, but am
afraid that I won't be able to
do so- Dear me! I am getting sleepy,
but must answer little joy's an-
napolis letter before I go to bed-
Boo! Boo! and sweet dreams. You joys!
Saturday morning 12th- my watch
says 5 minutes after seven, so
that I have overslept my-
self and don't know whether the
mail man has been here
or not- If he has, won't
it be too bad, as my Sweet
Joy won't get her letter!
Dear me! sweetheart, I
am awfully sorry! It's all
my own sleepy-headed
fault! yah! yah!- I was
only joking! Here he
comes now & I am in
very good time- Besides,
I am going to drive into
Havana, this morning, &
can mail it there without
any trouble- He! He! Ho! Ho!
Do you know how much your
dear Mantee weighs in his
light summer cloths? Just
148 lbs! What do you think
of that? Pretty good weight
to begin a Century with,
don't you think so? I never
weighed so much in my life,
and if I had good things to
eat, I would weigh 160 lbs!
My cheeks fairly stick out,
& as for my stomach, why
it resembles that of a
Washington Brewer!
Good-bye, you precious
children- Love & kisses
for my darling, darling
girls-
